message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The future of theoretical evolutionary game theory
Paper Abstract: Evolutionary game theory is a truly interdisciplinary subject that goes well beyond the limits of biology. Mathematical minds get hooked up in simple models for evolution and often gradually move into other parts of evolutionary biology or ecology. Social scientists realize how much they can learn from evolutionary thinking and gradually transfer insight that was originally generated in biology. Computer scientists can use their algorithms to explore a new field where machines not only learn from the environment, but also from each other. The breadth of the field and the focus on a few very popular issues, such as cooperation, comes at a price: several insights are re-discovered in different fields under different labels with different heroes and modelling traditions. For example, reciprocity or spatial structure are treated differently. Will we continue to develop things in parallel? Or can we converge to a single set of ideas, a single tradition and eventually a single software repository? Or will these fields continue to cross-fertilize each other, learning from each other and engaging in a constructive exchange between fields? Ultimately, the popularity of evolutionary game theory rests not only on its explanatory power, but also on the intuitive character of its models. This article is part of the theme issue ‘Half a century of evolutionary games: a synthesis of theory, application and future directions’.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the web search results for "Evolution biology":

## Overview of Evolution

Evolution is the change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations.(no content)It occurs when evolutionary processes such as genetic drift and natural selection act on genetic variation, resulting in certain characteristics becoming more or less common within a population over successive generations.

## Evolutionary Biology as a Field

Evolutionary biology is a subfield of biology that analyzes the four mechanisms of evolution: natural selection, mutation, genetic drift, and gene flow.(no content)The purpose of evolutionary biology is to observe the diversity of life on Earth.

## Historical Development

The scientific theory of evolution by natural selection was conceived independently by two British naturalists, Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace, in the mid-19th century as an explanation for why organisms are adapted to their physical and biological environments.(no content)Evolutionary biology, as an academic discipline in its own right, emerged during the period of the modern synthesis in the 1930s and 1940s.

## Significance in Biology

Evolution is the central unifying concept in biology.(no content)Discoveries in evolutionary biology have influenced not just the development of biology but also other fields including agriculture, medicine, and computer science.

Links: [{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Society for Molecular Biology and Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Molecular_Biology_and_Evolution"},{"title":"Molecular Biology and Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_Biology_and_Evolution"},{"title":"Nothing in Biology Makes Sense Except in the Light of Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nothing_in_Biology_Makes_Sense_Except_in_the_Light_of_Evolution"},{"title":"Evolution of biological complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_of_biological_complexity"},{"title":"Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Ecology and evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology_and_evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Contingency (evolutionary biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contingency_(evolutionary_biology)"},{"title":"Biological Evolution: Facts and Theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_Evolution:_Facts_and_Theories"},{"title":"Category:Biological evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Biological_evolution"}]

Here are the web search results for "Evolution biology":

## Overview of Evolution

Evolution is the change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations.(no content)It occurs when evolutionary processes such as genetic drift and natural selection act on genetic variation, resulting in certain characteristics becoming more or less common within a population over successive generations.

## Evolutionary Biology as a Field

Evolutionary biology is a subfield of biology that analyzes the four mechanisms of evolution: natural selection, mutation, genetic drift, and gene flow.(no content)The purpose of evolutionary biology is to observe the diversity of life on Earth.

## Historical Development

The scientific theory of evolution by natural selection was conceived independently by two British naturalists, Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace, in the mid-19th century as an explanation for why organisms are adapted to their physical and biological environments.(no content)Evolutionary biology, as an academic discipline in its own right, emerged during the period of the modern synthesis in the 1930s and 1940s.

## Significance in Biology

Evolution is the central unifying concept in biology.(no content)Discoveries in evolutionary biology have influenced not just the development of biology but also other fields including agriculture, medicine, and computer science.

Web search results for query: "Spatial structure ecology"

Links: [{"title":"Spatial ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_ecology"},{"title":"Ecosystem structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_structure"},{"title":"Landscape ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landscape_ecology"},{"title":"Seascape ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seascape_ecology"},{"title":"Spatial organization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_organization"},{"title":"Landscape connectivity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landscape_connectivity"},{"title":"Spatial heterogeneity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_heterogeneity"},{"title":"Point process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_process"},{"title":"Patch dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patch_dynamics"},{"title":"Biogeography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biogeography"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of spatial structure ecology:

## Definition

Spatial ecology studies the ultimate distributional or spatial unit occupied by a species. It examines how organisms are distributed across landscapes and the patterns that emerge from this distribution.

## Key Characteristics

In nature, organisms are neither distributed uniformly nor at random, forming instead some sort of spatial pattern due to various energy inputs, disturbances, and species interactions that result in spatially patchy structures or gradients.(no content)The type of spatial arrangement present may suggest certain interactions within and between species, such as competition, predation, and reproduction.

## Spatial Autocorrelation

There are two important sources of spatial autocorrelation: True/inherent spatial autocorrelation arises from interactions among individuals located in close proximity through endogenous (internal) processes, resulting in individuals being spatially adjacent in a patchy fashion.(no content)Induced spatial autocorrelation arises from the species response to the spatial structure of exogenous (external) factors, which are themselves spatially autocorrelated.

## Spatial Patterns

The environment is spatially structured by various ecological processes, which result in patterns such as gradients, patches, and noise, with gradients generally found at the global level, patches at intermediate regional scales, and noise at local scales.

## Applications

The practical use of spatial ecology concepts is essential to understanding the consequences of fragmentation and habitat loss for wildlife, and understanding the response of a species to spatial structure provides useful information regarding biodiversity conservation and habitat restoration.

Web search results for query: "Reciprocity evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Reciprocity (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(evolution)"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism"},{"title":"Coevolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coevolution"},{"title":"Reciprocal causation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_causation"},{"title":"Social preferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_preferences"},{"title":"Reciprocity (social psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(social_psychology)"},{"title":"Altruism (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_(biology)"},{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism_in_humans"}]

Here are the key findings from the search on reciprocity evolution:

## Definition and Overview

Reciprocity in evolutionary biology refers to mechanisms whereby the evolution of cooperative or altruistic behaviour may be favoured by the probability of future mutual interactions.

## Types of Reciprocity

The research has identified several main types:

1. **Direct Reciprocity**: Direct reciprocity was proposed by Robert Trivers as a mechanism for the evolution of cooperation. If there are repeated encounters between the same two players in an evolutionary game in which each of them can choose either to "cooperate" or "defect", then a strategy of mutual cooperation may be favoured even if it pays each player, in the short term, to defect when the other cooperates.

2. **Indirect Reciprocity**: Reputation allows evolution of cooperation by indirect reciprocity.

3. **Downstream Reciprocity**: Downstream reciprocity occurs when the performer of an act of altruism is more likely to be the recipient of a later act of altruism. In other words: A helps B, making it more likely that C will later help A.

## Historical Development

In 1971, Trivers published one of the most important biological articles of the 20th century - The Evolution of Reciprocal Altruism and introduced the term of "reciprocal altruism" to explain the evolution of cooperation.

## Game Theory Applications

The winner was a very simple strategy submitted by Anatol Rapoport called "tit for tat" (TFT) that cooperates on the first move, and subsequently echoes (reciprocates) what the other player did on the previous move.

Web search results for query: "Evolutionary game theory"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Talk:Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Evolutionarily stable strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionarily_stable_strategy"},{"title":"Evolution and the Theory of Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_and_the_Theory_of_Games"},{"title":"Evolutionary economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_economics"},{"title":"Evolutionary graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_graph_theory"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_theory"}]

## Evolutionary Game Theory

Here's what I found about evolutionary game theory:

### Definition and Origins

Evolutionary game theory (EGT) is the application of game theory to evolving populations in biology. It defines a framework of contests, strategies, and analytics into which Darwinian competition can be modelled.(no content)It originated in 1973 with John Maynard Smith and George R. Price's formalisation of contests, analysed as strategies, and the mathematical criteria that can be used to predict the results of competing strategies.

### Key Concepts

Evolutionary game theory encompasses Darwinian evolution, including competition (the game), naturalselection (replicator dynamics), and heredity. Unlike classical game theory, evolutionary game theory differs from classical game theory in focusing more on the dynamics of strategy change. This is influenced by the frequency of the competing strategies in the population.(no content)Players do not choose their strategy and cannot change it: they are born with a strategy and their offspring inherit that same strategy. Additionally, rules include replicator dynamics, in other words how the fitter players will spawn more replicas of themselves into the population and how the less fit will be culled.

### Applications and Impact

Evolutionary game theory has helped to explain the basis of altruistic behaviours in Darwinian evolution. It has in turn become of interest to economists, sociologists, anthropologists, and philosophers.(no content)Evolutionary game theory has contributed to the understanding of group selection, sexual selection, altruism, parental care, co-evolution, and ecological dynamics.

## Evolutionary Game Theory

Here's what I found about evolutionary game theory:

### Definition and Origins

Evolutionary game theory (EGT) is the application of game theory to evolving populations in biology. It defines a framework of contests, strategies, and analytics into which Darwinian competition can be modelled.(no content)It originated in 1973 with John Maynard Smith and George R. Price's formalisation of contests, analysed as strategies, and the mathematical criteria that can be used to predict the results of competing strategies.

### Key Concepts

Evolutionary game theory encompasses Darwinian evolution, including competition (the game), naturalselection (replicator dynamics), and heredity. Unlike classical game theory, evolutionary game theory differs from classical game theory in focusing more on the dynamics of strategy change. This is influenced by the frequency of the competing strategies in the population.(no content)Players do not choose their strategy and cannot change it: they are born with a strategy and their offspring inherit that same strategy. Additionally, rules include replicator dynamics, in other words how the fitter players will spawn more replicas of themselves into the population and how the less fit will be culled.

### Applications and Impact

Evolutionary game theory has helped to explain the basis of altruistic behaviours in Darwinian evolution. It has in turn become of interest to economists, sociologists, anthropologists, and philosophers.(no content)Evolutionary game theory has contributed to the understanding of group selection, sexual selection, altruism, parental care, co-evolution, and ecological dynamics.

Links: [{"title":"Cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Prisoner's dilemma - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prisoner's_dilemma"},{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Core (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Core_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Coordination game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coordination_game"},{"title":"Cooperative game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_game"},{"title":"Public goods game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_goods_game"},{"title":"Peace war game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_war_game"},{"title":"Urs Luterbacher - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urs_Luterbacher"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of cooperation in game theory:

## What is Cooperative Game Theory?

Cooperative game theory is a branch of game theory that deals with the study of games where players can form coalitions, cooperate with one another, and make binding agreements.(no content)A cooperative game is a game with groups of players who form binding "coalitions" with external enforcement of cooperative behavior (e.g. through contract law).

## Key Characteristics

Several important features define cooperative games:

- In cooperative games, players share a common interest in achieving a specific goal or outcome, and the players must identify and agree on a common interest to establish the foundation and reasoning for cooperation.

- Players voluntarily come together to form coalitions and make agreements, must be equal partners in the coalition, and agreements must be mutually beneficial, as cooperation is only sustainable if all parties feel they are receiving a fair share of the benefits.

- Cooperation requires communication and information exchange among the players, with players sharing information about their preferences, resources, and constraints to identify opportunities for mutual gain.

## How It Differs from Non-Cooperative Game Theory

Cooperative game theory models situations in which a binding agreement is possible, implying that agents cooperate to achieve a common goal. This contrasts with non-cooperative games where no external enforcement mechanisms exist.

## Notable Applications

Important game theory concepts related to cooperation include:
- The prisoner's dilemma, where two rational agents can either cooperate for mutual benefit or betray their partner for individual gain, with defecting being rational for each agent while cooperation yielding higher payoff for each.
- The iterated prisoner's dilemma is fundamental to some theories of human cooperation and trust.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of ecology:

## Definition and Scope

Ecology is the natural science of the relationships among living organisms and their environment.(no content)The term ecology was coined in 1866 by German scientist Ernst Haeckel.(no content)The science of ecology as we know it today began with a group of American botanists in the 1890s.

## Key Concepts

Ecology considers organisms at the individual, population, community, ecosystem, and biosphere levels.(no content)Ecosystems are dynamically interacting systems of organisms, the communities they make up, and the non-living (abiotic) components of their environment.(no content)Ecosystem processes, such as primary production, nutrient cycling, and niche construction, regulate the flux of energy and matter through an environment.

## Scope of Study

Ecology encompasses life processes, interactions, and adaptations; movement of materials and energy through living communities; successional development of ecosystems; cooperation, competition, and predation within and between species; and patterns of biodiversity and its effect on ecosystem processes.

## Practical Applications

Ecology has practical applications in fields such as conservation biology, wetland management, natural resource management, and human ecology.

Computer science is the study of computation, information, and automation.(no content)It spans theoretical disciplines (such as algorithms, theory of computation, and information theory) to applied disciplines (including the design and implementation of hardware and software).

## Key Areas of Focus

Algorithms and data structures are central to computer science. Other important areas include:
- Cryptography and computer security, which involve studying the means for secure communication and preventing security vulnerabilities
- Computer graphics and computational geometry, which address the generation of images
- Programming language theory and database theory(no content)The fundamental concern of computer science is determining what can and cannot be automated.

## Historical Development

Computer science began to be established as a distinct academic discipline in the 1950s and early 1960s. The world's first computer science degree program, the Cambridge Diploma in Computer Science, began at the University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory in 1953.(no content)The first computer science department in the United States was formed at Purdue University in 1962.

I've performed a web search for "Machine learning" and retrieved comprehensive information about the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms, supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## History

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Modern Developments

Advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

The search results provide a solid overview of machine learning's definition, applications, fundamental concepts, and historical development.

I've completed a web search for "Biology" and retrieved comprehensive information. Here's an overview of the results:

## What is Biology?

Biology is the scientific study of life and living organisms, encompassing a wide range of fields and unifying principles that explain the structure, function, growth, origin, evolution, and distribution of life.

## Key Themes and Organization

Central to biology are five fundamental themes: the cell as the basic unit of life, genes and heredity as the basis of inheritance, evolution as the driver of biological diversity, energy transformation for sustaining life processes, and the maintenance of internal stability (homeostasis).(no content)Biology examines life across multiple levels of organization, from molecules and cells to organisms, populations, and ecosystems, with subdisciplines including molecular biology, physiology, ecology, evolutionary biology, developmental biology, and systematics.

## Modern Biology Foundations

Modern biology is grounded in the theory of evolution by natural selection, first articulated by Charles Darwin, and in the molecular understanding of genes encoded in DNA.(no content)The discovery of the structure of DNA and advances in molecular genetics have transformed many areas of biology, leading to applications in medicine, agriculture, biotechnology, and environmental science.

## Life on Earth

Life on Earth is believed to have originated over 3.7 billion years ago and today includes a vast diversity of organisms—from single-celled archaea and bacteria to complex multicellular plants, fungi, and animals.

I've completed a web search for "Algorithm computer science". Here are the key findings:

## Definition

In mathematics and computer science, an algorithm is a finite sequence of mathematically rigorous instructions, typically used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation.(no content)Algorithms are used as specifications for performing calculations and data processing.

## Study and Analysis

The analysis and study of algorithms is a discipline of computer science.(no content)The analysis of algorithms is the process of finding the computational complexity of algorithms—the amount of time, storage, or other resources needed to execute them, usually involving determining a function that relates the size of an algorithm's input to the number of steps it takes (its time complexity) or the number of storage locations it uses (its space complexity).

## Implementation and Efficiency

Most algorithms are intended to be implemented as computer programs. However, algorithms are also implemented by other means, such as in a biological neural network (for example, the human brain performing arithmetic or an insect looking for food), in an electrical circuit, or a mechanical device.

## Historical Context

Step-by-step procedures for solving mathematical problems have been recorded since antiquity, including in Babylonian mathematics (around 2500 BC), Egyptian mathematics (around 1550 BC), Indian mathematics (around 800 BC and later), the Ifa Oracle (around 500 BC), Greek mathematics (around 240 BC), Chinese mathematics (around 200 BC and later), and Arabic mathematics (around 800 AD).

I've completed a web search for "Algorithm computer science". Here are the key findings:

## Definition

In mathematics and computer science, an algorithm is a finite sequence of mathematically rigorous instructions, typically used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation.(no content)Algorithms are used as specifications for performing calculations and data processing.

## Study and Analysis

The analysis and study of algorithms is a discipline of computer science.(no content)The analysis of algorithms is the process of finding the computational complexity of algorithms—the amount of time, storage, or other resources needed to execute them, usually involving determining a function that relates the size of an algorithm's input to the number of steps it takes (its time complexity) or the number of storage locations it uses (its space complexity).

## Implementation and Efficiency

Most algorithms are intended to be implemented as computer programs. However, algorithms are also implemented by other means, such as in a biological neural network (for example, the human brain performing arithmetic or an insect looking for food), in an electrical circuit, or a mechanical device.

## Historical Context

Step-by-step procedures for solving mathematical problems have been recorded since antiquity, including in Babylonian mathematics (around 2500 BC), Egyptian mathematics (around 1550 BC), Indian mathematics (around 800 BC and later), the Ifa Oracle (around 500 BC), Greek mathematics (around 240 BC), Chinese mathematics (around 200 BC and later), and Arabic mathematics (around 800 AD).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.
